Line 27: Line 27:  
*Contrary to popular belief, especially among newer editors, [[Wikipedia:Polling is not a substitute for discussion|debates are not a vote]]. Administrators use [[Wikipedia:Consensus|rough consensus]] to determine the outcome. The process of rough consensus requires administrators to occasionally ignore opinions (sometimes called "!votes") because they are against policy, made in bad faith, etc. If you are reviewing a debate and find yourself trying to decide if a !vote should be ignored per the rough consensus guidelines, and doing so or not doing so would likely affect the outcome, then this is not the kind of debate that you, as a non-admin, ought to be closing.

*In general, XfDs other than [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|AfDs]] are probably not good candidates for non-admin closure, except by those who have extraordinary experience in the XfD venue in question. If there is a serious backlog on one of these venues, consider asking a very familiar admin who closes many of this type of discussions for their advise. Many of these venues have complicated criteria to consider, employ complicated templates, require additional logging elsewhere, or require the use of bots to run jobs to complete the tagging or other cleanup tasks that are required. If a non-admin closes such a discussion and does not take all of the steps, it can create a mess.

= Non admin deletion debate closures =
    +
−
I will have to give you first a disclaimer, that all of what I am about to say is my own personal opinion, based on my observation of others and my own conduct prior to adminship. == Which debates should a non-admin close or not close? ==
 
== Which debates should a non-admin close or not close? ==
  +
=== Appropriate closures ===
−
=== Non-admin closures of XfD's should be limited to the following types of closures ===
+
Non-admin closures of XfD's should be limited to the following types of closures:
 
* Unanimous or nearly unanimous '''keep''' after a full 5-day listing period, absent any contentious debate among participants.
 
* Unanimous or nearly unanimous '''keep''' after a full 5-day listing period, absent any contentious debate among participants.
−
* ''Snowball clause'' closes as '''speedy keep''', where it is absolutely obvious that no other outcome other than keep is possible, after several (eg. 6 or more) participants have !voted keep, and nobody voted for any other outcome (even neutral) or left a comment or asked a question which could be interpreted as hesistation to !vote keep.
+
* [[Wikipedia:Snowball clause|Snowball clause]] closes as '''[[WP:Speedy keep|speedy keep]]''', where it is absolutely obvious that no other outcome other than keep is possible. Specific criteria to use: (a) six or more participants have supported keeping the page; (b) no editor other than the nominator has opposed keeping the page or even supported another outcome, left a comment, or asked a question which could be interpreted as hesitation to support keeping the article; (c) the nominator has not added a lot of comments and is not still attempting to make his/her case, and (d) the process has gone on for at least a full day.
      +
=== Inappropriate closures ===
−
=== Non-admin closure is not appropriate in any of the following situations ===
+
Non-admin closure is not appropriate in any of the following situations:
−
* One or more editor other than the nominator has !voted delete, redirect, or neutral or voiced '''any''' concern about keep outcome, and the debate has not completed its current 5-day listing. (even relisted debates must complete the relisted 5-days).
    ⚫
* If the editor has participated in the debate in any way, even to simply make a comment or to relist the debate.
−
* Debates that are less than 5 days listed, currently unanimous keep, but could be seen as an ''uphill battle''; in-particular if the nominator is adding a lot of discussion and still attempting to make his/her case. Even if you are certain the outcome will be keep in such a case, an early close will almost certainly result in a delrev. At delrev you will undoubtedly be scolded for the early non-admin close.
  −
* If the result will require administrator action, eg. delete, move over redirect, unprotect, or merge page histories.
+
* If the result will require action by an administrator:
  +
** Deletion
⚫
* If the non-admin concerned has participated in the debate in any way, including making a comment, !voting, or relisting the debate.
    +
** Moving an article into a page (such as a redirect) that can't be accomplished by a regular editor
  +
** Unprotecting a page
  +
** Merging page histories
  +
* If the debate has not completed its current 5-day listing, except for snowball clause closes that meet the criteria above. (These criteria pertain to relisted debates as well - such debates must complete the full 5 day period except for snowball clause closes.)
  +   +
Inappropriate early closes will almost certainly result in a successful request to redo the process, at [[Wikipedia:Deletion review]]. Inappropriate early closes thus waste everyone's time.
     
=== Pitfalls to avoid ===
 
=== Pitfalls to avoid ===
⚫
*Contrary to popular belief, especially among newer editors, debates are not a vote. They are a !vote. Rough consensus is used by administrators to determine the outcome. The process of rough consensus requires administrators to occasionally ignore certain !votes, because they are against policy, made in bad faith, etc. If you are reviewing a debate and find yourself trying to decide if a !vote should be ignored per the rough consensus guidelines, and doing so or not doing so would likely affect the outcome, then this is not the kind of debate that a non-admin had ought to be closing.
  ⚫
*In general XfD's other than AfD are probably not good candidates for non-admin closure, except by those who have extraordinary experience in the XfD venue in question. If there is a serious backlog on one of these venues, consider asking a very familiar admin who closes alot of this type of discussion for their advise. many of these venues have complicated criteria to consider, employ complicated templates, require additional logging elsewhere, or require the use of bots to run jobs to complete the tagging or other cleanup tasks that are required. If a non-admin closes such a discussion and does not take all of the steps, it can create a mess.
  ⚫
*In particular, IfD's should be avoided; images are frequently transcluded into articles, templates and user pages. Admins closing these type of debates often have to verify the "what links here" special page and determine if a bunch of other cleanup needs to be done... such as removing the "deletable image caption" templates everywhere the image is used. Those who regularly close these venue debates likely know how to use bots, scripts and third-party tools to help them do so.
        ⚫
*Contrary to popular belief, especially among newer editors, [[Wikipedia:Polling is not a substitute for discussion|debates are not a vote]]. Administrators use [[Wikipedia:Consensus|rough consensus]] to determine the outcome. The process of rough consensus requires administrators to occasionally ignore opinions (sometimes called "!votes") because they are against policy, made in bad faith, etc. If you are reviewing a debate and find yourself trying to decide if a !vote should be ignored per the rough consensus guidelines, and doing so or not doing so would likely affect the outcome, then this is not the kind of debate that you, as a non-admin, ought to be closing.
⚫
